author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: In Video, a Defiant Zelensky Says, ‘We Are Here’
description: The 44-year-old president of Ukraine videotaped himself in Kyiv as Russian forces closed in on the capital, vowing to fight them to the end.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — As Russian missiles bombarded the Ukrainian capital Kyiv on Friday, President Volodymyr Zelensky seemed to go missing. Italy’s prime minister even told his own parliament, in a tremulous voice, that Mr. Zelensky had missed a planned call with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Judge Jackson’s Rulings: Detailed, Methodical and Leaning Left
description: Most of her opinions came from her time as a trial judge, and some scholars said such writings offered only hints about a judge’s legal philosophy.
content: WASHINGTON — If Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, President Biden’s Supreme Court pick, is confirmed, she will almost immediately confront a docket for its next term filled with polarizing issues, including the fate of affirmative action in higher education, the role race should play in drawing voting districts and whether businesses open to the public may discriminate against gay couples on religious grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How California Could Be Affected by the Ukraine-Russia Conflict
description: The latest updates on the invasion and an explanation of how California gas prices could be affected.
content: Thursday was Day 1 of the first major land war in Europe in decades. The Russian invasion of Ukraine is a grim, unsettling development and one that has, rightfully, eclipsed the local stories typically highlighted in this newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Ukraine on TV: We’ve Seen This Before. And We’ve Never Seen Anything Like It.
description: As the invasion unfolded, images straight out of Cold War nightmare dramas butted up against 21st-century politics.
content: If you are more than a few decades old, the invasion of Ukraine was horrific but familiar. It was what TV had taught you to expect since childhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: Florence + the Machine’s Conflicted Coronation, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Bonnie Raitt, Kehlani, Mahalia and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Stanley Reed
title: Why the Toughest Sanctions on Russia Are the Hardest for Europe to Wield
description: Moscow relies on the money it makes by selling oil and gas, but that energy fuels Europe’s economy and heats its homes.
content: The punishing sanctions that the United States and European Union have so far announced against Russia for its invasion of Ukraine include shutting the government and banks out of global financial markets, restricting technology exports and freezing assets of influential Russians. Noticeably missing from that list is the one reprisal that would cause Russia the most pain: choking off the export of Russian fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Invention of the Index
description: Dennis Duncan discusses “Index, a History of the,” and Brendan Slocumb talks about “The Violin Conspiracy.”
content: You probably take the index for granted. It might be hard to remember that the handy list of subjects at the back of a book, with the corresponding page numbers on which each subject is discussed, had to be invented. This happened in the early 13th century, and on this week’s podcast, Dennis Duncan talks about his new book, “Index, a History of the,” and about the earliest examples of the form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Gets Serious About Ukraine
description: Hosts did their best to bring levity to their shows on an otherwise somber day.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
title: In North Africa, Ukraine War Strains Economies Weakened by Pandemic
description: Egypt imports most of its wheat from Russia and Ukraine, and is looking for alternative suppliers. And Tunisia was struggling to pay for grain imports even before the conflict.
content: CAIRO — On the way to the bakery, Mona Mohammed realized Russia’s war on Ukraine might have something to do with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Ukraine and the Mirage of Energy Independence
description: Domestic oil and gas production in the U.S. boomed in recent years. But the country and its allies remain reluctant to impose sanctions on Russian energy that would damage their economies.
content: HOUSTON — It may be time to pluck that old cardigan out of the closet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Maryland lifts its statewide mask mandate for schools, effective immediately.
description: The decision gives local school districts the power to decide whether to require face coverings.
content: A Maryland legislative committee on Friday approved the State Board of Education’s decision to allow all 24 local school districts to decide whether to require face coverings in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Rapp Learn
title: The Pacific Spiny Lumpsucker Is Armed to the Teeth
description: The diminutive predator is a terrible swimmer but thrives in the intertidal zone thanks to odd evolutionary adaptation.
content: The nightmare of the Pacific spiny lumpsucker starts with the teeth: needle-sharp, lining the rim of bulbous lips. A single fin crowns the fish’s head like a mohawk, and spiked studs cover nearly every inch of its body, recalling an armored car from a “Mad Max” movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Miller
title: Why Is Putin at War Again? Because He Keeps Winning.
description: Russia understands that it’s militaries, not economies, that do the fighting.
content: There is no world leader today with a better track record when it comes to using military power than President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Whether against Georgia in 2008, Ukraine in 2014 or in Syria since 2015, the Russian military has repeatedly converted battlefield successes into political victories. Russia’s rearmament over the past decade and a half has been unmatched by a comparable increase in Western capabilities. So it is no surprise why Russia feels emboldened to use its military power while the West stands by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Are We Measuring Our Lives in All the Wrong Ways?
description: The philosopher C. Thi Nguyen believes that to understand modern life, we need to understand how games work.
content: When we play Monopoly or basketball, we know we are playing a game. The stakes are low. The rules are silly. The point system is arbitrary. But what if life is full of games — ones with much higher stakes — that we don’t even realize we’re playing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Karasik
title: Day Jobs
description: What your favorite writers might have done if they hadn’t written.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Free Options for Filing Your Taxes
description: Many of the no-cost online services have age or income limits. But some are available to anyone.
content: It’s tax-filing season, and whether you go to an accountant or use online tax software, filing a return can be expensive. But there are free options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: Conversation and Conflict, as Warhol Meets Basquiat
description: Paul Bettany and Jeremy Pope give memorable performances as the odd couple artists in Anthony McCarten’s new play, “The Collaboration.”
content: LONDON — Opposite art world titans attract in “The Collaboration,” a new play that opened Thursday at the Young Vic Theater here. Chronicling the creative partnership between Andy Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat during the 1980s, Anthony McCarten’s play offers bravura performances from Paul Bettany and Jeremy Pope as the two cultural icons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘How Beautiful We Were’ and ‘The Cult of We’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: HOW BEAUTIFUL WE WERE, by Imbolo Mbue. (Random House, 384 pp., $18.) Mbue’s sweeping fable, charting the struggle between a fictional African village and an American oil company, was one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2021. According to our reviewer, Omar El Akkad, “Mbue is masterly at shading in the spaces where greed and guilt intermingle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: On Capitol Hill, Democrats celebrate Judge Jackson while Republicans pledge a respectful review.
description: With backers calling the judge a “slam-dunk” for the Supreme Court, Republicans said they would give her a fair hearing.
content: Senate Democrats and progressive activists on Friday celebrated the nomination of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court while Republicans promised an exhaustive though respectful review of the first Black woman put forward for a seat on the high court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yaryna Serkez
title: Young Ukrainians, We Want to Hear From You
description: For Ukrainians born in 1991 or later, what does it mean to be living in an independent Ukraine?
content: Three decades ago, Ukraine gained its independence, and a nation that had to endure almost 70 years of Soviet subjugation could finally see a future in which democracy and freedom would thrive. But Ukraine’s story after 1991 was to be anything but a fairy tale: two revolutions, economic havoc and endless political crises. And Russia, the always troublesome larger neighbor that could never quite accept the fact that Ukraine wanted to chart its own path, invaded and annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014 and fueled a separatist war in the country’s east that killed about 13,000 Ukrainian soldiers and civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Will Kyiv Fall?
description: Ukrainians are battling to defend their capital against advancing Russian troops.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict. I’m your host, Carole Landry. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Laughing With the Queer Comedians Running the Show
description: Building on a long tradition of antic gay humor, a new wave of young male talents have adopted a for-us, by-us approach — and reinvented the genre.
content: There’s a phrase that magazine editors use when we’re trying to convince our colleagues that someone deserves a story written about them: that the person is “having a moment.” When applied to an individual, it’s both a recognition and a bestowal, affirmation of the artist’s contribution to the culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Inflation is a worry for 9 in 10 Americans polled.
description: A survey shows concern across generations and parties, contributing to a dour view of the economy.
content: The fastest inflation in decades is contributing to Americans’ dour view of the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: After Trump Surge, a Liberal Democrat in South Texas Shifts Tactics
description: In her second run for Congress, Jessica Cisneros has moved from pitching progressive policies to attacking the incumbent Democrat, Representative Henry Cuellar.
content: LAREDO, Texas — Two years ago, a 26-year-old immigration lawyer named Jessica Cisneros came within 3.6 percentage points of pushing out the longtime Democratic congressman here, running aggressively on the progressive vision of the national liberals who had bankrolled her insurgent campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Avian Flu Spreading Through Eastern U.S. Worries Poultry Farms
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 25, 2022.
content: “Scientists always assumed the next pandemic would be a respiratory influenza. We were wrong with Covid, but it’s these kinds of viruses that keep us awake at night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: C.D.C. Study Raises Questions About Agency’s Isolation Guidelines
description: Many people with Omicron infections may still be contagious beyond five days of isolation, a new report suggests.
content: More than half of people who took a rapid antigen test five to nine days after first testing positive for the coronavirus or after developing Covid-19 symptoms tested positive on the antigen test, according to a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Ana Swanson
title: Biden Hits Russia With Broad Sanctions for Putin’s War in Ukraine
description: The penalties will affect Russia’s biggest banks, its weapons industry, its largest energy company and families close to President Vladimir V. Putin. The country’s stock market has plummeted.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, vowing to turn President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia into a “pariah,” announced tough new sanctions on Thursday aimed at cutting off Russia’s largest banks and some oligarchs from much of the global financial system and preventing the country from importing American technology critical to its defense, aerospace and maritime industries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia says it will limit access to Facebook, a major platform for dissent.
description: Since President Vladimir V. Putin launched his attack on Ukraine, many Russians have taken to social media to express their anger.
content: MOSCOW — The Russian government said it was partially limiting access to Facebook for restricting some pro-Kremlin news media accounts, a move that could make it harder for Russians to share their anger over their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A Canadian leader with Ukrainian roots puts Putin in the ranks of ‘reviled European dictators.’
description: Canada has a large population with Ukrainian roots, including Chrystia Freeland, the deputy prime minister, whose interest in Ukrainian independence dates to the Soviet era.
content: In Canada, a country with one of the world’s largest Ukrainian diasporas, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has been met with particularly visceral emotion, including from the deputy prime minister, Chrystia Freeland, the daughter of a Ukrainian-Canadian mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
description: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
content: MEDYKA, Poland — Cradling her 3-year-old son, who was gravely ill with cancer, the 25-year-old Ukrainian mother staggered into Poland on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Stuart A. Thompson
title: ‘I’ll Stand on the Side of Russia’: Pro-Putin Sentiment Spreads Online
description: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.
content: The day before Russia invaded Ukraine, former President Donald J. Trump called the wartime strategy of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia “pretty smart.” His remarks were posted on YouTube, Twitter and the messaging app Telegram, where they were viewed more than 1.3 million times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A special edition on the war in Ukraine.
content: A day after Russia invaded Ukraine, the Russian Defense Ministry said its forces had destroyed more than 70 military targets, including 11 airfields, a helicopter and four drones. Russian forces also captured the former nuclear power plant at Chernobyl, north of Kyiv, the site of the 1986 nuclear disaster. Explosions were reported in Kyiv, Kharkiv and elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Talk to Kids About Ukraine
description: Young people have access to more news streams than ever, and many are concerned. Here’s how to address their questions.
content: If your kids have heard about the Russian invasion of Ukraine, they may be feeling nervous. Thanks to social media and online outlets, young people have access to more news sources than ever. Many are bound to have questions about the history between the two countries and how the clash may affect the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: They Fled for Greener Pastures, and There Were Weeds
description: City dwellers, who retreated to rural areas in the pandemic, now see drawbacks, from pests and social isolation to the difficulty of finding day care and health care.
content: For Andrew Joseph, the unexpected challenge of rural living was summed up in a single word: beavers. Mr. Joseph was enchanted by baby beavers swimming in the brook on his four-acre property in the town of Saugerties, N.Y., where he and his partner, Paul Pearson, have been sheltering since March 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manan Luthra
title: Covid Drove More Australians Away From Cities. Will They Go Back?
description: As restrictions ease, will the appeal of fewer people, a lower risk of transmission and more personal space prove to be enduring?
content: If during the last two years you thought of leaving your locked-down Australian city for the freedom of a country town, you weren’t alone. A report released last week by the Regional Australia Institute found that in 2020 and 2021, net migration from state capitals to regional areas was more than twice as high as in 2018 and 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Partial Measures
description: Why aren’t the U.S. and its allies imposing tougher sanctions?
content: Western leaders have described the sanctions that they have imposed on Russia as “strong” and “severe.” And the sanctions will damage the Russian economy. After the U.S. and Britain announced new measures yesterday — making it harder for Russian companies to raise money or import goods — an index of Moscow’s stock market fell more than 30 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: ‘Abrupt Changes’: China Caught in a Bind Over Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
description: China has presented itself as a defender of sovereign independence. But its reluctance to denounce Russia’s aggression forces it into an awkward position.
content: As Russian troops have poured into Ukraine, officials in Beijing have fumed at any suggestion that they are betraying a core principle of Chinese foreign policy — that sovereignty is sacrosanct — in order to shield Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
title: Swedish Olympic Star Gives Away Gold Medal to Protest Beijing’s Abuses
description: In a rare rebuke of Beijing, Nils van der Poel, a speedskater, handed one of his gold medals to the daughter of Gui Minhai, a book publisher imprisoned in China.
content: The Swedish skating star Nils van der Poel jumped for joy on the podium when he received his gold medal for the men’s 10,000-meter speedskating race at the Beijing Winter Olympics. Years of grueling training had brought him the world record-breaking victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: An Iranian Director’s Rule: ‘Always Focus on Ordinary People’
description: Asghar Farhadi, who has won two Oscars, says stories about the rich and famous “are not part of my emotional bank.”
content: Asghar Farhadi made his first film at age 13, shot with an 8-millimeter camera, about two boys who agree to share an abandoned radio on alternate days, but who then discard it because neither can listen to their favorite nightly program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: This Is Just the Beginning
description: Bombs are falling in Europe. And the future is uncertain.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Far-right militias in Europe plan to confront Russian forces, a research group says.
description: The apparent mobilization of far-right groups could be problematic for the Ukrainian government
content: The Russian attack on Ukraine has prompted a flurry of activity among far-right European militia leaders, who have taken to the internet to raise funds, recruit fighters and plan travel to the front lines to confront the country’s invaders, according to a research group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Democrats Have Bigger Problems Than the Squad
description: Having immobilized the president’s agenda and plunged their party into disarray, moderate and conservative Democrats are casting around for someone to blame.
content: The milquetoast politics of moderate and conservative Democrats in Congress are backfiring big time on their party and threatening its hold on power before the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Bappi Lahiri, India’s ‘Disco King,’ Dies at 69
description: He helped popularize the genre with some of the country’s biggest hits of all time, including “I Am a Disco Dancer.”
content: Bappi Lahiri, an Indian film composer who combined the melodrama of Bollywood film plots with the flamboyance of disco’s electronic orchestra sound, setting off a pop craze in India that earned him the nickname “Disco King,” died on Feb. 15 in Mumbai. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Ballot Rejections in Texas Spike After New Voting Law
description: Ahead of Tuesday’s primary, about 30 percent of absentee ballots were rejected in the state’s most populous counties. In 2020, the statewide rejection rate was less than 1 percent.
content: Local election officials in Texas have rejected thousands of absentee ballots based on requirements set by the state’s new election law, an alarming jump that risks potentially preventing some Texans from voting in Tuesday’s primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kazin
title: Democrats Used to Be Able to Get Things Done. What Happened?
description: They need a social movement powerful enough to force liberal elites to advance sweeping reforms, rather than tinker around the edges of a broken system.
content: Why have Joe Biden’s ambitions for a new New Deal stalled, if not completely run aground? The pitch for the president’s Build Back Better program on the White House website certainly sounds like something Franklin Roosevelt could have said during the Great Depression: It calls “the hard work and ingenuity of the American people” the greatest “economic engine” the world has ever seen, but charges that “for too long, the economy has worked great for those at the top, while working families continually get squeezed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How the World Is Seeking to Put Pressure on Russia
description: Several countries and the European Union have imposed a variety of sanctions in response to Vladimir V. Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine.
content: The United States, the European Union and several other countries and entities have expanded their economic sanctions against Russia as punishment for its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: A Limestone Mansion on the Upper East Side Sells for $56 Million
description: The house topped sales in February, in a market that included boldface names like Norman Lear, Anthony Rapp and Nathan Lane.
content: A six-story, limestone mansion on the Upper East Side, with a long list of amenities, including a lower-level fitness center with a pool, gym and massage room, finally sold after more than six years on the market and several price cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Putin’s Russia to Pinball
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: COME OVER COME OVER, by Lynda Barry. (Drawn & Quarterly, $21.95.) Barry’s now-classic collection of comics about the wonders and horrors of middle school, starring 14-year-old Maybonne, is back in this reissue. All the anxiety and insecurity are still there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Sale of Leases for Wind Farms Off New York Raises More Than $4 Billion
description: The auctioned areas are expected to generate enough power for nearly 2 million homes once turbines are built.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States government netted a record $4.37 billion on Friday from the sale of six offshore wind leases off the coasts of New York and New Jersey, a major step in the Biden administration’s goal of ushering in a future powered by renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ivry
title: How Bridget Everett, Star of HBO’s ‘Somebody, Somewhere,’ Spends Her Sundays
description: The longtime chanteuse of the New York cabaret scene starts the day with biscuits and family and ends it with martinis and friends.
content: The HBO series “Somebody Somewhere,” which concludes its first season this Sunday, tells the story of Sam, a middle-aged woman who has returned to her hometown in Kansas to look after an ailing sister. The story begins after her sister’s death, with Sam adrift in a state of mourning. A ragtag group of new friends, and singing, helps her cope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Foo Fighters Made a Horror Film. Because Why Not?
description: Dave Grohl shares how the band went from filming funny music videos to making “Studio 666,” due Feb. 25, and discusses a coming album.
content: In the three decades that Dave Grohl has been a rock star, he has recorded with the likes of Stevie Nicks and Paul McCartney, directed documentaries, performed for presidents and been inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: This Novel Theory of Negotiation Also Works in the Real World
description: The correct way to negotiate: Identify the value created through reaching a deal and split it 50-50.
content: Clam pizza is considered a treat in New Haven, Conn., where Yale students line up for it. So when Barry Nalebuff wanted to introduce his Yale School of Management students to a key concept in negotiating theory, he explained it in terms of dividing a 12-slice clam pizza between two hungry people. Read closely and you’ll learn a technique that you can use whether you’re a parent of squabbling kids or a titan of finance (or both!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Prized Possessions
description: Tell us about your most cherished belongings.
content: A recent Times article reported on bizarre stories of people being buried with their cars, with some saying they were inspired by accounts that ancient Egyptians were buried with their possessions. How do you feel about the idea of burying extravagant items with their owners after they die?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: New C.D.C. Guidelines Suggest 70 Percent of Americans Can Stop Wearing Masks
description: The agency issued a new set of recommendations intended to help communities live with the virus and get back to normal life.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday offered a new strategy to help communities across the country live with the coronavirus and get back to some version of normal life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: The New York Philharmonic Brings Back the Standards
description: Manfred Honeck led a program that teased at novelty, then settled into well-known works by Mendelssohn and Dvorak.
content: It had to end at some point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. Officials Repeatedly Urged China to Help Avert War in Ukraine
description: Americans presented Chinese officials with intelligence on Russia’s troop buildup in hopes that President Xi Jinping would step in, but were repeatedly rebuffed.
content: WASHINGTON — Over three months, senior Biden administration officials held half a dozen urgent meetings with top Chinese officials in which the Americans presented intelligence showing Russia’s troop buildup around Ukraine and beseeched the Chinese to tell Russia not to invade, according to U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Champions League Final Will Be Played in Paris, Not Russia
description: European soccer officials stripped the game from St. Petersburg as punishment for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and said they would not host games on Russian soil “until further notice.”
content: European soccer’s governing body on Friday voted to move this season’s Champions League final, the showcase game on the continent’s sporting calendar, to Paris as punishment for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Scholar of the Early Republic Wins American History Book Prize
description: The New-York Historical Society award goes to Alan Taylor, whose “American Republics” emphasizes the fragility of the American experiment from the beginning.
content: Alan Taylor, the author of “American Republics: A Continental History of the United States, 1783-1850,” has been named the winner of the New-York Historical Society’s 2022 Barbara and David Zalaznick Book Prize, which is awarded each year for the best work of American history or biography.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Workers Vote for Union at an Arizona Store
description: The victory was the union’s first outside Buffalo and appeared to underscore its momentum in organizing company employees across the country.
content: First they won in Buffalo. Now they’ve scored a victory on the other side of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: The International Energy Agency ponders market intervention over the Ukraine invasion.
description: A meeting discussed “increased concerns” in energy markets, and appeared to signal the group was getting ready to intervene, perhaps with a release of oil.
content: The International Energy Agency said representatives from its 31 member countries met Friday to discuss the impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine on global energy markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Zelensky says Russian saboteurs are in Kyiv and he is Moscow’s prime target.
description: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that Russian saboteurs had entered Kyiv, the capital, and that he was “target No. 1” for Russian forces, followed by his family.
content: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that Russian saboteurs had entered Kyiv, the capital, and that he was “target No. 1” for Russian forces, followed by his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What to See and Experience Live in New York This Spring
description: ‘Funny Girl’ and ‘A Strange Loop’ on Broadway, Ashwini Ramaswamy’s dances, Olivia Rodrigo’s pop takeover: what our critics and writers are looking forward to this season.
content: ‘TAKE ME OUT’ Peanuts and crackerjacks may not be available at Second Stage’s Hayes Theater, but anyone who thinks that live theater is the ultimate spectator sport should root for the Broadway revival of Richard Greenberg’s comedy. Set in the locker room of a professional baseball team, the play stars Jesse Williams (“Grey’s Anatomy”) as a big-shot player who wants to come out as gay. Openly queer athletes are somewhat more common than when Greenberg wrote the play, which debuted at the Public Theater in 2002 and later won three Tony Awards. But they remain a rarity in team sports. So the play’s conversations around excellence, sexuality and the boundaries between public and private lives, should still make it around the bases. Scott Ellis directs, and Jesse Tyler Ferguson (“Modern Family”) and Patrick Adams (“Suits”) co-star. ALEXIS SOLOSKIPreviews begin March 10; opens April 4 at the Hayes Theater, Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Maggie Astor and Catie Edmondson
title: Trump Praises Putin, Leaving Republicans in a Bind
description: G.O.P. leaders, while condemning Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, were silent on comments made by the former president. Some figures on the right amplified them.
content: As Russia prepared to strike Ukraine and the United States rushed to defend neighboring allies in Europe, former President Donald J. Trump had nothing but admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Should Be Done About the Gender Pay Gap in Sports?
description: What do you think of U.S. Soccer’s pledge to equalize pay between its men’s and women’s national teams?
content: This week, the United States Soccer Federation pledged to equalize pay for its men’s and women’s national teams as part of a settlement that included a $24 million payment to a group of players for the women’s team who had sued the organization for gender discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Key Inflation Gauge Is Still Rising, and War Could Make It Worse
description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred measure is at a four-decade high. Rising gas prices tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could push it up further.
content: A measure of inflation that the Federal Reserve watches closely accelerated again in January, hitting a new 40-year high and speeding up on a monthly basis as food and energy prices climbed sharply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘No Exit’ Review: Who’s Bluffing?
description: In this diverting thriller, a young woman discovers a kidnapping in progress while snowed in at a rest stop
content: In “No Exit,” the director Damien Power gets straight to business: Darby (Havana Rose Liu) is stuck in rehab and groaning her way through another group therapy session when she gets a call about her mother, who has suffered a brain aneurysm. Darby — edgy and impetuous — hot-wires a nurse’s car and zooms off toward the hospital where her mother is. Unfortunately, Darby is foiled by a massive snowstorm, which keeps her stranded at a remote rest stop with four strangers and no cellphone service.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews C. Thi Nguyen
description: A conversation with the philosopher of games.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with C. Thi Nguyen. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: East Meets West at Lincoln Center
description: And celebrities walk in the Blue Jacket Fashion Show for prostate cancer awareness.
content: The New York Philharmonic held its annual Lunar New Year concert and gala on Feb. 8 at Alice Tully Hall. The concert, which mixed Asian and Western classical music, was followed by a dinner that celebrated the Year of the Tiger. And on Feb. 17, the sixth annual Blue Jacket Fashion Show, which raises awareness of prostate cancer among Black men, was held at Moonlight Studios. Numerous celebrities walked the runway, including Al Roker, Mario Cantone and Don Lemon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Growing Up Onscreen With ‘My Brilliant Friend’
description: Margherita Mazzucco and Gaia Girace have starred in the HBO adaptation of Elena Ferrante’s novels since they were in middle school. The new season will be their last.
content: ROME — When the actresses Margherita Mazzucco and Gaia Girace walk around Naples, fans ask them for selfies, autographs and even hugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia Batters Ukraine With Artillery Strikes as West Condemns Invasion
description: Explosions were reported over Kyiv, the capital. Several countries announced severe new sanctions, as Vladimir Putin remained resolute about his decision to invade.
content: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Russia continued its attack on Ukraine early Friday, one day after it invaded the country by land, sea and air, killing more than 100 Ukrainian soldiers and civilians and ominously touching off a pitched battle at the highly radioactive area around the Chernobyl nuclear reactor that melted down in 1986.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Dion
title: Seeking a Father for My Child (Relationship Optional)
description: Nearing 40, I decided to separate dating from mating.
content: Two days before I left South Dakota, Rex and I sat talking beneath the open hatchback of my car. In the distance, a lightning storm moved toward us over the open expanse of the Great Plains, churning the sky a murky purple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Scenes from Kharkiv: Battle wreckage, the boom of artillery, and people sheltering in the subway.
description: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — The thuds of artillery start as a low-decibel rumble, but rattle the rib cage as you get closer. A crossroads at the northern entrance of Kharkiv is about as close to the front lines as anyone would wish to be on Friday, as Ukrainian soldiers waged a fierce battle to push Russian forces away from the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Thanks, Jane Brody, for Nudging Us to Be Better
description: After blazing a trail for women and pioneering science-based service journalism, the popular author of The Times’s Personal Health column is saying goodbye.
content: ﻿A few years back, I organized a sold-out event for The Times. The planners marveled at my success, but I knew the real reason so many people wanted to attend. I had invited a secret weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Separating Dating From Mating
description: And, why we dream about past loves.
content: Nearing 40 and wanting to have a biological child, Katharine Dion decided to separate dating from mating. As she writes in her Modern Love essay, “I resolved to have a child outside of the context of love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: U.S. minorities experienced high rates of Covid-related discrimination, a study finds.
description: Those of Asian ethnicity, who have been victims of several high-profile bias crimes during the pandemic, reported the highest rates of racist comments and threats related to the pandemic.
content: People in the United States who belong to racial and ethnic minority groups reported experiencing Covid-related discrimination far more often than white people during the pandemic, and far more often than had been estimated, according to a new study that is one of the largest to date on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Ukraine War Bares U.S. Army Delay in Creating New ‘Monuments Officers’
description: Civilian specialists are tracking the threat to landmarks in Ukraine as the U.S. Army struggles after more than two years to appoint new cultural heritage preservation specialists modeled after the “Monuments Men.”
content: For months before the bombs started falling, Hayden Bassett watched over the cultural riches of Ukraine — the cathedrals of Kyiv, the historic buildings of Lviv, museums across the country and the ancient burial sites that dot its steppes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Stone Sues Jan. 6 Panel to Block Access to His Cellphone Records
description: The political operative and close ally of former President Donald J. Trump joined at least 19 other witnesses who have gone to court to stonewall the inquiry.
content: WASHINGTON — Roger J. Stone Jr., a close ally of former President Donald J. Trump, on Thursday sued members of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, asking a federal court to block them from obtaining logs of his texts and phone calls as part of what he deemed an effort to persecute him and other conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Driven by the Potential for Joy’: Comedies Are the Thing This Spring
description: We spoke to four playwrights — JC Lee, Charly Evon Simpson, Bryna Turner and Ana Nogueira — whose new shows invite audiences to laugh (even if some laughs catch in the throat).
content: “I want to feel like everyone is going to be OK,” the playwright JC Lee said.

title: How Covid Stole Our Time and How We Can Get It Back
description: ‘Depressing Math’ can help you live a more fulfilled life.
content: I have good news and bad news for you. Let’s start with the bad: a concept I call Depressing Math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R.E. Hawley
title: Adopting the Tetris Mind-Set
description: How I find my center amid a stream of falling video game blocks.
content: In an unlit corner of my mind, the pieces are always moving, twirling around one another in constant reconfiguration like a raucous group folk dance. The pile grows and it shrinks, its jagged edge producing new cliffs and caverns waiting to be scaled or unsealed. As soon as each piece is nestled into a carefully prepared corner or laid flush against the side of a pile, a new piece begins its doomed free fall, and the puzzle begins again, each rotation spawning solutions that hang in the air like mist until a decision is made — ideally in time to prevent disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: When a Baseball Lockout Complicates Christmas Dinner
description: Things got tricky when Cardinals second baseman Tommy Edman spent holiday time with his siblings, who were also employed by M.L.B. teams.
content: SAN DIEGO — The baseball lockout is complicated on many levels, but perhaps nowhere was it more convoluted than in the home of the Edmans in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Todd Anderson
title: Disney Takes Visitors to a Galaxy Far, Far Away
description: Star Wars: Galactic Starcruiser, opening at Walt Disney World, is part luxury hotel, part theme park ride, part role-playing game. But it will cost you.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Carina Ja had a skeptical look on her face as she glanced around the lobby of her Walt Disney World hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Why Is ‘Cyrano’ Still So Potent? Ask Anyone Who’s Loved at All.
description: The 19th-century French play is quite adaptable, as numerous stage and film versions have shown, including the latest musical starring Peter Dinklage.
content: When the French playwright Edmond Rostand penned “Cyrano de Bergerac” in the late 19th century, he couldn’t have imagined its durability — translations into countless languages, stage productions across the world and several high-profile film adaptations. The newest of those, “Cyrano” (opening in theaters Feb. 25), supplements Rostand’s beloved story with musical numbers by members of the rock band the National — a decidedly contemporary touch. But this is nothing new; Rostand’s has proved a malleable text, and its film adaptations tell us much about the kind of stories audiences were responding to when they were made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Why didn’t the U.S. cut off Russia from SWIFT? It’s complicated.
description: Removing access to the financial messaging service would be the most severe penalty but could have unwanted consequences, including compromising energy exports to Europe.
content: President Biden said on Thursday that the United States and Europe were united in their efforts to confront Russian aggression toward Ukraine with aggressive sanctions. However, there was one area where he suggested disagreement: SWIFT.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: The White House releases a plan to help people who are especially vulnerable to Covid-19.
description: The plan involves making masks and tests more accessible, but has been criticized by some disability advocates for not going far enough to protect the most vulnerable.
content: The Biden administration announced on Thursday it was taking several steps to make masks and coronavirus tests more accessible to people with disabilities, following criticism from the disability community that the country’s top leadership has been slow to act to protect the country’s most vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Defeat Trump, Now More Than Ever
description: The struggle against authoritarianism, at home and abroad.
content: The democratic nations of the world are in a global struggle against authoritarianism. That struggle has international fronts — starting with the need to confront, repel and weaken Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Katie Rogers
title: The U.S. and Europe target Putin with sanctions.
description: The new penalties are a provocative step given how rarely governments, including the United States, take aim at foreign leaders.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and Europe moved on Friday to personally penalize President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for his invasion of Ukraine, imposing sanctions aimed at freezing his wealth while continuing to try to cripple his military and economic capabilities through other new restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Ashford
title: It’s Official: The Post-Cold War Era Is Over
description: Russian troops are attacking Ukraine. For so long, U.S. policymakers have grappled with how to prevent such a moment. Now, they must answer a different question.
content: The world has witnessed several potential turning points signaling the end of the post-Cold War period: the global financial crisis, the Arab Spring, the Covid-19 pandemic. Now, with competition between the great powers triggering a major war on the European continent, we have it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Harris and Uli Knörzer
title: The Queer Young Comics Redefining American Humor
description: For years, gay male performers were left out of the comedy landscape or tokenized within it. Now, a new wave of entertainers are succeeding by playing to themselves.
content: WHEN DEWAYNE PERKINS was a teenager growing up on the South Side of Chicago, he would occasionally turn to Google in search of, if not himself, somebody who at least came close. What he found was a void. “I remember Googling gay comics and nothing coming up, especially gay Black comics,” says Perkins, whose blazingly funny stand-up work ranges from sweet to goofy to raunchy. “I am not a fan of being a token. I don’t think it’s fun to be ‘the first.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Moving Cross Country for the ‘Real Deal’
description: Kate Adams met Brook Nelson on Instagram in early 2019. By that July, Ms. Adams had moved across the country to further their relationship.
content: On Feb. 11, 2019, Kathrine Taylor Adams was brushing her teeth and scrolling through Instagram when she paused to read a personal ad that Brook Ann Nelson had written for an account that functioned as a dating board for queer women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia confirms that it controls the former Chernobyl nuclear plant.
description: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it was working with Ukrainian guards to ensure the safety of the former plant, while Ukraine said Russian forces were holding the facility’s personnel hostage.
content: SOCHI, Russia — Russia’s Defense Ministry said in a statement on Friday that its paratroopers had taken control of the territory around the former Chernobyl nuclear plant in northern Ukraine and were working with Ukrainian guards to ensure the safety of its facilities, contradicting Ukrainian claims that Russian forces were holding the plant’s personnel hostage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Rosenberg
title: Michael Stipe, Another Outsider at the Art Fair
description: The R.E.M. singer-songwriter is parting with works from his collection of Southern artists — but their inspiration lingers on.
content: In the video for R.E.M.’s first single, “Radio Free Europe,” the band’s members can be seen walking in slow-motion through the Summerville, Ga., home and yard of the self-taught artist and Baptist minister Howard Finster. A landscape of lush foliage packed with folk art sculptures and salvaged objects, Finster’s “Paradise Garden” combined the regional traditions of evangelism and do-it-yourself object making and had become a popular pilgrimage spot for South Georgia artists, musicians and other creative types. The garden gave R.E.M.’s 1983 video a dreamlike quality and a recognizably Southern sense of place, setting it apart from the other hits on MTV at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: European Leaders Agree to a Second Wave of Russia Sanctions
description: The E.U. agreed to freeze the assets of President Putin and foreign minister Sergey Lavrov, while other measures will hit Russia’s access to technology
content: BRUSSELS — European leaders meeting into the early hours of Friday hammered out an agreement over a new set of sanctions aimed more broadly at the Russian economy and at President Vladimir V. Putin himself, as his troops advanced in their invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: How Being Inclusive Can Be Insulting
description: We shouldn’t pretend that a piece of music by a Black artist is classical if it isn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronika Melkozerova
title: I’m in Kyiv, and It Is Terrifying
description: I feel fear crawling in my guts.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — On Thursday, I woke up at dawn to the sound of blasts. I jumped out of bed, puzzled. Maybe it was a dream? But then I heard another loud blast, and then another one. Kyiv was shaking. I reached for my phone and read that President Vladimir Putin of Russia had ordered his army to attack Ukraine. They had started bombarding us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: This puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon makes us look up and down.
content: ACROSTIC — This is a fabulous passage, one of my favorites in a while. It’s from “How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming,” by Mike Brown, the astronomer who discovered Eris, a dwarf planet, in the outer reaches of our solar system in 2005. The events that followed are like a work nightmare in which we discover some creative new efficiency but, in doing so, cause our favorite colleague to be laid off. That colleague here is Pluto, and most of us love it like a planet. (I so want to write “him,” because Pluto makes me think of the Disney dog.) Don’t believe me? Take the poll:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A groundbreaking nomination who’s unlikely to reshape the Supreme Court.
description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s replacement of Justice Stephen G. Breyer substitutes a liberal for a liberal and would not shift the basic dynamic of the court.
content: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee, will bring fresh perspectives to the job if she is confirmed. She may serve for decades. But there is little reason to think she can do much to alter the court’s conservative trajectory in the short term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: South Carolina Is Locked at No. 1 Ahead of Shuffling
description: The Gamecocks have only one loss, but parity across the Power 5 leagues, especially the Big Ten and Big 12, should make for intense jockeying ahead of the tournament.
content: As the spring approaches, women’s college basketball is inching closer and closer to a symbolic milestone. It’s one many people might never have noticed, and one that won’t have any impact on the quality or intensity of games.

title: How Simple Exercises May Save Your Lower Back
description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
content: The past few years have not been kind to my lower back. Between the physical tolls of pregnancy, parenting and working from home, I have a constant stiff, achy feeling in my lower spine. I am not alone: It’s estimated that up to 80 percent of Americans will develop lower back pain during their lifetime, with 15 to 20 percent of adults reporting it in an average year.

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Joaquina Kalukango Isn’t Afraid to Speak Up Anymore
description: Before leading her first Broadway musical in “Paradise Square,” she had long deferred to others in the rehearsal room — until she realized how much she has to share.

title: Russian forces are meeting more resistance near Kyiv and Kharkiv than farther south, analysts say.
description: Independent security analysts said Russian forces in the east and the south of Ukraine were maneuvering with less resistance than those forces that were farther north and approaching the cities of Kyiv and Kharkiv, where the attacks were less sophisticated and the Ukrainian military had succeeded in engaging Moscow’s army.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is proposing new disclosure requirements for large short sellers. Officials say it could help them sort out market disruptions.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission is proposing a new set of reporting requirements for short-selling activity that it says will help regular people and market watchdogs better understand what’s going on in the stock market and how short sellers are affecting the prices of individual stocks.

title: ‘Killing Eve’ Is Back for a Final Season. Here’s Where We Left Off.

content: Vladimir Putin’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine is advancing from the east, the south and toward Kyiv in the north. title: Along Mexico’s Riviera Maya, Tourists, Drugs and Violence
description: On the stretch of beaches from Cancún to Tulum, there have been a number of gang-related incidents in which international visitors have been killed or injured. But that hasn’t stopped the vacationers from coming.
content: The headlines out of Mexico have been jarring. Two women were killed in the crossfire when rival gangs started shooting at a popular sidewalk restaurant in Tulum. Gunmen battled on a beach near Puerto Morelos as tourists scrambled into a Hyatt hotel for cover. A killer-for-hire bought a day pass to an all-inclusive resort in Playa del Carmen to carry out a hit in a poolside snack bar.

title: Why Was a Catholic Hospital Willing to Gamble With My Life?
description: Overturning Roe v. Wade isn’t just about abortion.
content: More than 20 states are poised to ban or severely restrict abortion if the Supreme Court decides to overturn or undermine Roe v. Wade this year. We know these laws and regulations will have a devastating effect on women’s rights and liberty, but many people do not realize how deeply they will reach into maternal medicine. You can’t take away the right to abortion without risking the health and lives of all women who become pregnant.

content: In June 2018, a mutual friend invited Jennifer Wilder and Brandon Perlman to a party at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum in Manhattan with the intention of setting them up. Though they had never met before, Ms. Wilder and Mr. Perlman had a lot in common, the friend told her.

content: John Landy, a scholarly Australian who became the second man, after Roger Bannister of England, to run the mile in under four minutes, and who later dueled Bannister in a race that became known as the Mile of the Century, died on Thursday at his home in Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia. content: MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — Nestled in the heart of South Beach, Flamingo Park has been a haven for handballers in South Florida since the 1970s. A half-mile from Miami Beach’s party scene, the quiet handball courts here have seen their share of world champions and are home to a consistent crew of players, most of them between the ages of 60 and 80. Fifty years of play have battered the once-vibrant pastel walls of the courts, which are now primed with a fresh coat of white paint. But you’re still likely to find the same motley crews and trash talkers of years past.
